Award.AwardTitle: CANS 2016: 2016 Meeting of the Chinese-American Networking Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Consistent with NSF's mission to advance research and education, Research and Education (R&E) partnerships between the U.S. and China have contributed to the global exchange of knowledge in the advanced research/higher education enterprise for over 30 years. Since 1999, the Chinese American Networking Symposium (CANS) has played an integral part in these developments through annual meetings that are held in the U.S. and China in alternate years. The 2016 CANS workshop takes place in Houston, Texas and engages selected participants from both countries to discuss topics of mutual interest that revolve around R&E networks, their engineering, and ways in which network utilization can enhance science and education. In the tradition of prior workshops over the last nearly two decades, CANS 2016 fosters scientific communication between the U.S. and China, and brings together researchers from multiple scientific disciplines with network engineers and campus leaders in Information Technology to explore the most effective mechanisms to foster increased research collaborations. The project has the potential to broaden the dialogue between research and education communities as well as impact the next generation of researchers and network engineers by providing a better understanding of shared science goals, and engaging campus leadership on how best to support those science goals through high performance networking.

Technical areas of exploration include native IPv6 deployment and support end-to-end for driving science applications, as well as performance measurement based on active performance testing with Perfsonar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In October 2016, Internet2 coordinated the Chinese-American Symposium 2016 (CANS2016). This event focused on supporting the advanced networking needs of US and Chinese researchers and provided a continuum for the overall CANS program, continuing the legacy of ensuring the close and fruitful communication and collaboration between Chinese and American scientists, technologists, and network engineers that was initiated almost 20 years ago.  Supported in part by NSF and hosted by Rice University, the symposium was held on October 17-19, 2016 in Houston, Texas. This represented the 7th consecutive CANS meeting supported in part by NSF, and the 17th CANS meeting since the program’s inception.  For over 30 years, research and education partnerships between the US and China have grown due to inter-government agreements, scientific trends involving remote collaboration, an increased emphasis on global exchange of knowledge in higher education, and advanced network infrastructures that facilitate the exchange of ideas.  Since 1999, CANS has been part of these trends, holding annual meetings (alternating each year between China and the US) to discuss areas of mutual interest addressing R&E networks, their engineering, ways in which network utilization can enhance science and education, and other topics including cyberinfrastructure, global interoperability, and cybersecurity.

The symposium’s program included an additional goal of engaging more closely with researchers from both countries, and encouraging the representation of scientists and researchers from domains that have previously not been active in the program. This goal was achieved, with new domains represented, including telemedicine, astronomy, and bioinformatics. Additionally, participation of domain scientists, university administrators and university staff (e.g., users, network engineers, and identity architects) made for a unique cross-pollination of ideas and topics over the course of the three-day workshop.

CANS2016 gathered over almost 100 participants from three countries (the US, the UK, and China) and over 37 institutions. Out of these, 47 participants were from China, 52 from the US, and 2 from the UK. Women represented 17 of the 102 participants (16%) and approximately 15% of attendees were scientists from multiple disciplines.

CANS 2016, under the theme “One Network – One World” also served as a people network to improve existing, and enable new, US-China science collaborations. It included presentations that described science goals and technologies with a focus on networking and data movement as key enablers and working sessions that allowed technologists and domain scientists to work together to set goals and milestones. It featured keynote presentations from speakers from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, China Meteorological Administration, Tsinghua University, and participation from Internet2 members, including Rice University, University of Wisconsin-Madison, UCSD, National Institutes of Health, among others. Topics covered advancements in supercomputing, identity provider systems, high-throughput computing, and collaborative networking, and Transnational Education (TNE).  Science-related talks focused on how networks can be used for remote diagnosis of malaria, how meteorological data is collected and stored, what impact innovation and technology have on modern Chinese culture, and network requirements for large science instruments used in very-long-baseline interferometry. The program included collaborative working groups addressing network characterization and performance, IPv6, Identity Management, data transfer and high-throughput computing, and transnational education. The discussions on a variety of topics, particularly Transnational Education and ensuing technical and connectivity support, were also discussed with additional attendees as part of the program for events such as the 2017 Internet2 Global Summit and at GEANT’s TNC17.

CANS2016 also contributed to maintaining and advancing the critical dialogue between the research and education communities in the US and China, advanced networking organizations (Internet2, the China Education and Research Network (CERNET), and the China Science and Technology Network/China Networking Information Center (CSTNET/CNIC)) and their supported communities, organizations and institutions.

Since the symposium, Internet2 has fostered a number of activities, including regular calls with CERNET and CSTNET (the two Chinese R&E networks) in service of the needs of US universities and Internet2 members with activities in China and side meetings at the Internet2 Global Summit in April 2017 in Washington DC and at TNC17 in Linz, Austria, in May 2017.
